manifest.name: GitLab
manifest.description: GitLab plugin for Mattermost.

settings_schema.header: To set up the GitLab plugin, you need to register a GitLab OAuth app here https://gitlab.com/-/profile/applications.
settings_schema.footer: To report an issue, make a suggestion, or submit a contribution, [check the repository](https://github.com/mattermost/mattermost-plugin-gitlab).

settings.help_text: When true, instructs the plugin to use the preregistered GitLab OAuth application - application registration steps can be skipped. Requires [Chimera Proxy](https://github.com/mattermost/chimera) URL to be configured for the server. Can only be used with official gitlab.com. **This setting is intended to be used with Mattermost Cloud instances only.**
The base URL for using the plugin with a GitLab installation. Examples: https://gitlab.com or https://gitlab.example.com.
The client ID for the OAuth app registered with GitLab.
The client secret for the OAuth app registered with GitLab.
The webhook secret set in GitLab.
The AES encryption key used to encrypt stored access tokens.
(Optional) Set to lock the plugin to a single GitLab group.
(Optional) Allow the plugin to work with private repositories for subscriptions.
Allow the plugin to expand permalinks to GitLab files with an actual preview of the linked file.

options.display_name: Enable for public and private projects. This might leak confidential code into public channels

The webhook secret set in Gitlab.
Select the username of the user that the plugin will post with. This can be any user, the name and icon will be overridden when posting.
The AES encryption key used to encrypt stored access tokens.
(Optional) Set to lock the plugin to a single Gitlab group.
(Optional) The base URL for using the plugin with a Gitlab Enterprise installation. Example: https://gitlab.example.com

(Optional) Allow the plugin to work with private repositories. Enabling private repositories will require existing users to reconnect their accounts to gain access to private repositories. A message will be automatically be sent to affected users next time they load Mattermost alerting them of this.

manifest.name: AWS SNS
manifest.description: Send alert notifications from Amazon AWS CloudWatch to Mattermost channels via AWS SNS.

settings_schema.header: This plugin is used to receive alert notifications from [Amazon AWS CloudWatch](https://aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/) to Mattermost channels via AWS SNS.

settings.help_text:
The channels to send notifications to. Multiple channels can be specified. Format `teamname,channelname;teamname-2,channelname-2`. If the specified channels do not exist, the plugin will create the channels for you.
 
 Note: Must be the team and channel handle used in the URL. For example, in the following URL, set the value to `myteam,mychannel`: https://example.com/myteam/channels/mychannel.

List of users authorized to accept AWS SNS subscriptions to a Mattermost channel. Must be a comma-separated list of user IDs.
 
 Tip: Use the [mmctl user search](https://mattermost.com/pl/cli-mattermost-user-search) mmctl command to determine a user ID.
Generated token to validate incoming requests from AWS SNS.

manifest.name: Calls
manifest.description: Integrates real-time voice communication in Mattermost

settings_schema.header: Calls plugin enables voice calls with screensharing in channels. See [documentation](https://docs.mattermost.com/channels/make-calls.html) to learn more.

settings.help_text: When test mode is enabled, only system admins are able to start calls in channels. This allows testing to confirm calls are working as expected.
The local IP address used by the RTC server to listen on for UDP connections.
The local IP address used by the RTC server to listen on for TCP connections.
The UDP port the RTC server will listen on.
The TCP port the RTC server will listen on.
(Optional) The IP (or hostname) to be used as the host ICE candidate. If empty, it defaults to resolving via STUN.

(Optional) A port number to be used as an override for host candidates in place of the one used to listen on.
Note: this port will apply to both UDP and TCP host candidates
(Optional) The URL to a running RTCD service instance that should host the calls. When set (non empty) all calls will be handled by the external service.
The maximum number of participants that can join a call. If left empty, or set to 0, it means unlimited.
(Optional) A list of ICE servers (STUN/TURN) configurations to use. This field should contain a valid JSON array.
(Optional) The secret key used to generate TURN short-lived authentication credentials.
(Optional) The number of minutes that the generated TURN credentials will be valid for.
(Optional) When set to on it will pass and use configured TURN candidates to server initiated connections.
When set to true it allows call participants to share their screen.
When set to true it enables simulcast for screen sharing. This can help to improve screen sharing quality.
(Optional) When set to true, call recordings are enabled.
The URL to a running calls job service instance used for call recordings.
The maximum duration (in minutes) for call recordings. Value must be in the range [15, 180].

The audio and video quality of call recordings.
 Note: this setting can affect the overall performance of the job service and the number of concurrent recording jobs that can be run.
(Optional) When set to true, call transcriptions are enabled.
The speech-to-text model size to use. Heavier models will produce more accurate results at the expense of processing time and resources usage.
When set to true the RTC service will work in dual-stack mode, listening for IPv6 connections and generating candidates in addition to IPv4 ones.

When set to true, ringing functionality is enabled: participants in DM and GM channels will receive a desktop alert and a ringing notification when a call is started. Changing this setting requires a plugin restart.

settings_schema.header: Calls plugin enables voice calls with screensharing in channels. See [documentation](https://docs.mattermost.com/channels/make-calls.html) to learn more.

settings.help_text: When test mode is enabled, only system admins are able to start calls in channels. This allows testing to confirm calls are working as expected.
The IP address used by the RTC server to listen on.
The UDP port the RTC server will listen on.
The maximum number of participants that can join a call. If left empty, or set to 0, it means unlimited.
(Optional) The IP (or hostname) to be used as the host ICE candidate. If empty, it defaults to resolving via STUN.
(Optional) A list of ICE servers (STUN/TURN) configurations to use. This field should contain a valid JSON array.
(Optional) The secret key used to generate TURN short-lived authentication credentials.
(Optional) The number of minutes that the generated TURN credentials will be valid for.
(Optional) When set to true it will pass and use configured TURN candidates to server initiated connections.
When set to true it allows call participants to share their screen.
(Optional) The URL to a running RTCD service instance that should host the calls. When set (non empty) all calls will be handled by the external service.
(Optional) When set to true it enables the call recordings functionality.
The URL to a running calls job service instance used for call recordings.
The maximum duration (in minutes) for call recordings. Value must be in the range [15, 180].

manifest.name: GitHub
manifest.description: GitHub plugin for Mattermost.

settings_schema.header:
The GitHub plugin for Mattermost allows users to subscribe to notifications, stay up-to-date with reviews, see the status of pull requests at a glance, and other common GitHub actions - directly from Mattermost. 
 
 Instructions for setup are [available here](https://www.mattermost.com/pl/default-github-plugin#configuration).
settings_schema.footer: * To report an issue, make a suggestion or a contribution, [check the repository](https://github.com/mattermost/mattermost-plugin-github).

settings.help_text: Set to false if using GitHub Enterprise. When true, instructs the plugin to use the preregistered GitHub OAuth application - application registration steps can be skipped. Requires [Chimera Proxy](https://github.com/mattermost/chimera) URL to be configured for the server. Cannot be used with GitHub enterprise. **This setting is intended to be used with Mattermost Cloud instances only.**
The client ID for the OAuth app registered with GitHub.
The client secret for the OAuth app registered with GitHub.
The webhook secret set in GitHub.
The AES encryption key used to encrypt stored access tokens.
(Optional) Set to lock the plugin to a single GitHub organization.
(Optional) The base URL for using the plugin with a GitHub Enterprise installation. Example: https://github.example.com
(Optional) The upload URL for using the plugin with a GitHub Enterprise installation. This is often the same as your Base URL.

settings.display_name: Display Notification Counters in Left Sidebar
settings.help_text: When false, the counters showing the user how many open/assigned issues they have in Github will not be shown in the Left Hand Sidebar on desktop browsers.

(Optional) Allow the plugin to work with private repositories. When enabled, existing users must reconnect their accounts to gain access to private repositories. Affected users will be notified by the plugin once private repositories are enabled.

settings.display_name: Connect to private Repositories by default:
settings.help_text: (Optional) When enabled, /github connect command will let users connect to their github account and gain access to private repositories without explicitly mentioning private.
Allow the plugin to expand permalinks to GitHub files with an actual preview of the linked file.

options.display_name: Enable for public and private repositories. This might leak confidential code into public channels

settings.help_text: Allow the plugin to log the webhook event. The log level needs to be set to DEBUG.
In `Pushes` event notification, show commit author instead of commit committer.

settings_schema.footer: * To report an issue, make a suggestion or a contribution, [check the repository](https://github.com/mattermost/mattermost-plugin-github).

settings.help_text: When true, instructs the plugin to use the preregistered GitHub OAuth application - application registration steps can be skipped. Requires [Chimera Proxy](https://github.com/mattermost/chimera) URL to be configured for the server. Cannot be used with GitHub enterprise. **This setting is intended to be used with Mattermost Cloud instances only.**
The client ID for the OAuth app registered with GitHub.
The client secret for the OAuth app registered with GitHub.
The webhook secret set in GitHub.
The AES encryption key used to encrypt stored access tokens.

(Optional) The base URL for using the plugin with a GitHub Enterprise installation. Example: https://github.example.com
(Optional) The upload URL for using the plugin with a GitHub Enterprise installation. This is often the same as your Base URL.

manifest.name: Jira
manifest.description: Atlassian Jira plugin for Mattermost.

settings_schema.header: Please refer to the `/jira` command [**documentation**](https://mattermost.gitbook.io/plugin-jira/setup/installation#step-2-install-app-on-jira-server) to further configure the Jira plugin.
settings_schema.footer: Please refer to the `/jira` command [**documentation**](https://mattermost.gitbook.io/plugin-jira/setup/installation#step-2-install-app-on-jira-server) to further configure the Jira plugin. Specifically, [`/jira instance [un-]install`](https://mattermost.gitbook.io/plugin-jira/setup/installation#step-2-install-app-on-jira-server) and [`/jira webhook`](https://mattermost.gitbook.io/plugin-jira/setup/configuration#step-4-required-setup-webhooks-from-jira).

settings.display_name: Allow users to attach and create Jira issues in Mattermost:
settings.help_text:
When **false**, users cannot attach and create Jira issues in Mattermost. Does not affect Jira webhook notifications. Select **false** then disable and re-enable this plugin in **System Console > Plugins > Plugin Management** to reset the plugin state for all users. 
 
 When **true**, install this plugin to your Jira instance with `/jira install` to allow users to create and manage issues across Mattermost channels. See [documentation](https://about.mattermost.com/default-jira-plugin-link-application) to learn more.
The secret used to authenticate the webhook to Mattermost.
settings.regenerate_help_text: Regenerates the secret for the webhook URL endpoint. Regenerating the secret invalidates your existing Jira integrations.

settings.display_name: Mattermost Roles Allowed to Edit Jira Subscriptions:
settings.help_text: Mattermost users who can subscribe channels to Jira tickets.

options.display_name: Users who can manage channel settings

settings.display_name: Jira Groups Allowed to Edit Jira Subscriptions:
settings.help_text: Comma separated list of Group Names. List the Jira user groups who can create subscriptions. If none are specified, any Jira user can create a subscription. Jira groups restrictions are only applicable for a legacy instance installed on Jira 2.4 or earlier.

settings.display_name: Default Subscription Security Level to Empty:
settings.help_text: Subscriptions will only include issues that have a security level assigned if the appropriate security level has been included as a filter

settings.display_name: Additional Help Text to be shown with Jira Help:
settings.help_text: Additional Help Text to be shown to the user along with the output of `/jira help` command.
Hide detailed issue descriptions and comments from Subscription and Webhook messages
Autocomplete guides users through the available `/jira` slash commands.
Display subscription name in post when a subscription posts to a channel

manifest.name: Zoom
manifest.description: Zoom audio and video conferencing plugin

settings_schema.header: To set up this plugin you first need to create a Zoom App using a Zoom Administrator account. Visit the [documentation for configuration steps](https://mattermost.gitbook.io/plugin-zoom/installation/zoom-configuration).

settings.help_text: The URL for a self-hosted private cloud or on-prem Zoom server. For example, https://yourzoom.com. Leave blank if you're using Zoom's vendor-hosted SaaS service.
The API URL for a self-hosted private cloud or on-prem Zoom server. For example, https://api.yourzoom.com/v2. Leave blank if you're using Zoom's vendor-hosted SaaS service.

When true, OAuth will be used as the authentication means with Zoom. 
 When false, JWT will be used as the authentication means with Zoom. 
 If you're currently using a JWT Zoom application and switch to OAuth, all users will need to connect their Zoom account using OAuth the next time they try to start a meeting. [More information](https://mattermost.gitbook.io/plugin-zoom/installation/zoom-configuration).
When true, only an account administrator has to log in. The rest of the users will automatically use their Mattermost email to authenticate when starting meetings.
The client ID for the OAuth app registered with Zoom. Leave blank if not using OAuth.
The client secret for the OAuth app registered with Zoom. Leave blank if not using OAuth.
The AES encryption key used to encrypt stored access tokens.
settings.regenerate_help_text: Regenerates the encryption key for Zoom OAuth token. Regenerating the key invalidates your existing Zoom OAuth.

settings.help_text: The API key generated by Zoom, used to create meetings and pull user data.
The API secret generated by Zoom for your API key.
The secret used to authenticate the webhook to Mattermost.
settings.regenerate_help_text: Regenerates the secret for the webhook URL endpoint. Regenerating the secret invalidates your existing Zoom plugin.

settings.help_text: `Secret Token` taken from Zoom's webhook configuration page

```https://SITEURL/plugins/zoom/webhook?secret=WEBHOOKSECRET```

settings.help_text: The URL for a self-hosted private cloud or on-premise Zoom server. For example, https://yourzoom.com. Leave blank if you're using Zoom's vendor-hosted SaaS service.
The API URL for a self-hosted private cloud or on-premise Zoom server. For example, https://api.yourzoom.com/v2. Leave blank if you're using Zoom's vendor-hosted SaaS service.
The API Key generated by Zoom, used to create meetings and pull user data.
The API Secret generated by Zoom for your API key.
The secret used to authenticate the webhook to Mattermost.
settings.regenerate_help_text: Regenerates the secret for the webhook URL endpoint. Regenerating the secret invalidates your existing Zoom plugin.

manifest.name: Zoom
manifest.description: Zoom audio and video conferencing plugin for Mattermost 5.2+.
